title.narrative: Prosperity and Innovation in the Past and Future of Agriculture in Eastern Africa (PIPFA)

description.narrative: Despite the fact that approximately 85% of total agricultural output across the African continent is produced by small-holder farmers, with the small-holder farming sub-sector accounting for 75% of Kenya's total agricultural output, there remains a persistent imagining amongst some academics, policy makers and NGOs that African farming practices are static, inefficient and inherently vulnerable in the face of environmental change and population growth. These ideas have in turn supported a longstanding modernising paradigm whereby African agriculture is argued to require a host of 'new' technical inputs such as mechanisation, chemical fertilisers and pesticides, and hybrid and GM crops. This process has deep colonial roots and, in the wake of pressing issues surrounding climate change and population growth, has re-emerged in recent calls for a new African Green Revolution. However, this 'modernising' paradigm has failed to deliver sustainable prosperity, suggesting that alternative frameworks are required. By analysing how small-holder farmers in Eastern Africa innovate in daily practice, this project will reconsider why wholesale attempts at modernisation have often failed and, in the process, offer alternative ways toward prosperous rural livelihoods. Working with multisectoral partners currently active in food systems research and delivery, we challenge the 'modernisation' imperative by historicising contemporary farming practices in Kenya and diachronically exploring ongoing processes of innovation and ingenuity that seem to have been characteristic of African farming for centuries, arguing instead that these may offer crucial insights into the future of farming practice in the region. The premise that African farming systems have historically been diverse and highly adaptive draws upon a wealth of archaeological and historical material that demonstrates how they have developed in dynamic ways over several thousand years, continuously diversifying as they became integrated into expansive inter-continental exchange networks with SW Asia, India and China. Such processes continued into the 19th century when, with the formalisation of colonisation, new waves of domesticates and concepts surrounding soil and forest conservation were introduced by 'professional' colonial agricultural officers. Whilst many of these colonial interventions understood African agricultural systems as resistant to change (Anderson 2018; Beinhart 2000), we argue here for a more nuanced narrative wherein small-holders selectively adopted and propagated new ideas, practices, crops and materials (Moore 2018). In this view farmers experiment, generate knowledge, and selectively adopt the ideas of others on a daily basis. We argue that this historic process of creative innovation, selective valuation and intelligent (re-)combination is what constitutes what are often referred to (and often brought into opposition) as both 'tradition' and 'modernity' and that this historical reconceptualization offers an important new starting point for revaluing, supporting and extending farmers capabilities. Working with diverse partners we will co-design original empirical research with small-holder 'digital farmers' in Elgeyo-Marakwet Kenya. We have specifically chosen to work with partners from both the UK and Kenya and from academic, NGO, international and policy sectors so as to share diverse institutional practices and agenda and to co-design and deliver research that will stimulate institutional responses and specific policy recommendations. By working with, challenging, and supporting partners active in food systems research and delivery we aim to have multiple tangible impacts on policy making and farming livelihoods more broadly, thus demonstrating the important value of arts and humanities led multidisciplinary and transdisciplinary research.

We will develop a multisectoral partnership to share knowledge between research institutions, policy-makers and communities, reframe how we understand farmer innovation, and use this to support small-holders in Kenya and Eastern Africa more broadly. We will co-design research to generate new evidence on historical and contemporary innovation focussed on 'digital farmers' farmers in Elgeyo-Marakwet, Kenya. We will embed this knowledge into institutional practices to inform activities and generate commensurate impacts on farming livelihoods. This will be achieved through three objectives (Ob.1-3): Ob1. Build an interdisciplinary/intersectoral partnership: Beginning with co-production and co-design, utilising the local Marakwet Research Station and Citizen Scientist farmers, the partnership will design research activities and share knowledge among a diversity of academic and policy-oriented institutions including Elgeyo-Marakwet County (EMC), the University of Eldoret (UoE), British Institute in Eastern Africa (BIEA), East Africa Herbarium (EAH) and The Economics of Ecosystems and Biodiversity TEEB project (UNEP), as well as Pesticide Action Network (PAN-UK) and the Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew (KG) in the UK. These partners all work in food systems delivery and are open to questioning prevailing agricultural modernisation interventions and establishing a more dynamic understanding of historic and contemporary farmer innovation to inform future agricultural initiatives and create a new basis for supporting small-holder farmers as active agents of positive change. Through knowledge sharing workshops in Kenya and the UK and original empirical research (Ob2.) we will generate new data on small-holder innovation and explore our partners institutional strategies to effect policy change (Ob3.) Ob2. Generate an empirical base to reframe small-holder farmer innovation: We will reorient prevailing views of African farming as urgently requiring modernisation and external intervention by exploring the potential of small-holder innovation as the basis for sustainable agricultural futures. This perspective derives from a uniquely historical and anthropological approach which views farmers as agents of innovation rather than passive individuals brought into 'systems of innovation' created by corporate, governmental and economic structures. We hone in on farmers in the region who have come to portray themselves as 'digital' or 'enhanced'. Drawing on an archive of historic work by the PI, recent pilot research, a new program of farmer interviews and the specific expertise of the partners, we will co-design a programme that explores historic and contemporary farmer innovation through three workplans: WP1. Crop Diversity; WP2. Water, Soils, Pests and Fertility; WP3. Networks of Knowledge and Practice. We will use these to explore partners own strategies and develop specific policy recommendations (Ob3). Ob3: Turn equitable co-design and knowledge sharing into meaningful impacts through the partners: We will foster an equitable working environment within which diverse partners come together to explore reciprocal institutional perspectives and co-design a program of knowledge generation to inform their future strategies towards agronomic intervention. The partners will focus around specific workplans (Ob2.) and use project results to develop policy outcomes directed towards improving practice. All partners will specifically contribute to measures directed toward EMC government for immediate policy impacts and improved farmer support systems. All partners will also contribute to improved modelling within the UNEP TEEB project to effect wider research and policy frameworks. We will examine issues of capability and equality as a cross-cutting theme and work jointly to generate a series of novel engagements and dissemination media - on farm policy tours, vlogs/blogs, maps, policy papers and academic publications.
